text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian papers this morning:

- The right-wing Progress Party will become the second biggest party after the ruling Labour Party in September's election, according to a TV2 opinion poll released on Tuesday night. But experts and political leaders are sceptical of the poll's credibility.

- The central bank says lending to Norwegian households, companies and local governments is growing as quick as it did in the early 1980s. If the trend continues, lending will see an annual growth of 12.6 percent this year against 6.1 percent last year.

- Kjell Magne Bondevik, the Christian People's Party's candidate for prime minister in the September elections, wants to bridge income differences between people, giving more money to the weakest in society at the expense of the very rich.
- State-owned Telenor Mobil has seen an explosion in GSM mobile phone subscriptions in July when it recorded a net growth of 45,000 such subscriptions.
- Norwegian branded goods-based conglomerate Orkla has managed to secure a 20-year deal with PepsiCo in Sweden and is now seeking to forge a similar agreement for Norway.
- The Oslo Bourse Total index exceeded 1,300 points for the first time.
